_readme.note: THIS IS AN EXAMPLE FILE FOR REFERENCE PURPOSES ONLY
_readme.description: This file demonstrates how to structure brand style configurations for Adobe Target experiences. Nike is used as an example brand - you should create your own brand configuration based on your actual brand guidelines.
_readme.flexibility: IMPORTANT: These styles are SUGGESTIONS and DEFAULTS only. Users can override any value during their conversation. These are NOT strict rules - they provide consistency when users don't specify custom values.
_readme.usage: Copy this structure and customize all values to match your brand's design system, color palette, typography, and component styles.
_readme.integration: Reference these styles in your Target offer generation tools to maintain brand consistency across all experiences, but always allow user overrides.

nike.name: Nike (EXAMPLE ONLY)
nike.description: Example Nike brand style guidelines - FOR DEMONSTRATION PURPOSES. Replace with your actual brand styles. All values can be overridden by user during conversation.

generic.name: Generic Brand Template (STARTER TEMPLATE)
generic.description: TEMPLATE for creating custom brand styles - duplicate and modify for your brand. All values are suggestions and can be overridden.

fontFamilies.primary: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, sans-serif

_instructions.important: THIS FILE IS FOR EXAMPLE AND REFERENCE PURPOSES ONLY. Nike styles shown are approximations for demonstration.
_instructions.override_policy: These styles are DEFAULT VALUES and SUGGESTIONS ONLY. Users can and should override any value during their conversation with the AI. Think of this as a brand style guide, not as hard-coded rules.
_instructions.usage: This configuration provides consistent starting points for Adobe Target experiences while allowing full flexibility for customization.
_instructions.howToAdd: To add your own brand: 1) Copy the 'generic' template, 2) Rename it to your brand name, 3) Customize all values to match your actual brand guidelines.
_instructions.integration: Reference these styles in your Target offers using the brand name as the key (e.g., brandStyles['nike']), but always prioritize user-specified values.
_instructions.cssVariables: Use the cssVariablesTemplate to generate CSS custom properties for your brand.
_instructions.components: Component styles provide consistent UI patterns but should be treated as starting points, not requirements.

example.userOverride: User says 'use #000000 instead' → Use #000000, ignore brand config
example.generatingCSS: Replace {{tokens}} in cssVariablesTemplate with actual values from the brand configuration

bestPractices: Use brand styles as intelligent defaults, not strict rules
Always allow users to override any style value in conversation
Ask users if they want to use brand defaults or customize
Keep color values consistent with your design system
Define component styles for reusable UI patterns
Document any brand-specific design tokens or guidelines
